Authors:
V. V. Robin, C. K. Vishnudas, Pooja Gupta, Frank E Rheindt,
Daniel Hooper, Uma Ramakrishnan, Sushma Reddy
Title:
Two new genera of songbirds represent endemic radiations from
the Shola Sky Islands of the Western Ghats, India
Keywords:
phylogenetics, birds, Shola, passerine, montane,
sky-islands, taxonomy, tropics
Abstract:
Background: A long-standing view of Indian biodiversity is
that while rich in species, there are few endemics or in-situ
radiations. The Western Ghats biodiversity hotspot is an isolated
mountain range with many endemic species, particularly on the montane
sky islands. Understanding the origins of the montane-restricted species
is crucial to illuminate both taxonomic and environmental history.
Results: With evidence from genetic, morphometric, song, and plumage
data, we show that two montane songbirds, historically labeled as single
species of widespread Asian genera, each represent highly divergent
lineages that have diversified into three and four species endemic to
isolated sky-islands of the Western Ghats. These two lineages do not
group with the taxa in which they were previously classified but rather
are distinct early divergences in larger Asian clades of flycatchers and
babblers and therefore warrant new generic status. We designate the
Western Ghats shortwings as Sholicola and the laughingthrushes as
Montecincla. Divergence dating showed that both these montane groups
split from their Himalayan relatives during the Miocene, which is
coincident with a shift towards arid conditions that fragmented the
previously contiguous humid forest across peninsular India and isolated
these lineages in the Western Ghats. Conclusion: Our study reveals the
existence of two independent endemic radiations in the Shola Sky
Islands, highlighting the role of climate that may have resulted in
these ancient lineages. The endemic and highly divergent nature of these
unrecognized species underscores the dearth of knowledge about the
biogeography of the Asian tropics, even for comparatively well-known
groups such as birds, and the need for more rigorous systematic analysis
to inform biodiversity studies and conservation efforts.
